title: ISO 9001:2015 QMS Execution and Auditing Techniques
headline: Learn how to effectively implement and audit quality management system programmes with this free online course.
description: ISO 9001 has been upgraded with new elements to help companies meet customer and stakeholders' needs. This online course will disclose the challenges of the quality management systems of ISO 9001:2015 and explore the terminologies and principles of the revised standard. Understand the key requirement of each of the main clauses of the standard and review practical tips for implementing and auditing this revised standard.
courseDescription:
The ISO 9001 standard is part of the ISO 9000 family of quality management system standards that organisations use to determine their ability to regularly provide products and services that meet customer and other stakeholders' needs. ISO 9001:2015, the latest version, has been upgraded with several new elements to move companies to a higher level of excellence. We have developed this course to provide you with in-depth coverage of the revised requirements of ISO 9001:2015 with a solid conceptual understanding. It begins by introducing ISO 9001 and the objectives and maturity of quality management systems. We will outline the reasons for the ineffective implementation of ISO 9000 quality management systems in companies and the differences between quality control, quality assurance and quality management systems. You will study the historical evolution of ISO 9000 and the background of ISO 9001 releases. We provide information on the newly released ISO 9001 supplement, Annex SL and the reasons for the current 2015 revision.

Next, we explore the critical terms and definitions, either edited, modified or considered important for critically understanding the standards. Examine the terminology between ISO 9001:2008 and ISO 9001:2015. We demonstrate the seven principles of quality management systems that form the basis on which all the requirements of ISO 9001 have been written. We clarify the new ISO structure, terminologies and concepts cited at the end of the new revised ISO 9001:2015 standards. We review the product and services, interested parties, risk-based thinking, knowledge management and external providers. We share some practical tips for quality management systems auditors and implementers. We address the key requirements of each clause and the implications to organisations who intend to implement them or auditors who plan to audit the standard.

This course provides the ISO 9001:2015 transition roadmap and tips for implementing the revised standard effectively. Analyse the proposed eight steps and the new standard and timeframe to implement an ISO 9001 program successfully. Dr Kamran Moosa, your tutor, is the Chief Executive of the Pakistan Institute of Quality Control (PIQC). He is an experienced researcher and professor, an international trainer and consultant, author and advisor to national institutions in quality engineering and management. He has a wide range of global experience in the industrial, service and academic sectors. He presently contributes to many national and international forums to develop quality and business excellence. This course will benefit beginners, managers and professionals working in the quality management departments or other departments where ISO 9001 is implemented. Enrol and start learning today.

Start Course Now

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Quality Management System is an intuition program in organizations to ensure that a company fulfils its quality obligation towards the customer and in light of any mandatory standard required by other stakeholders.
  • The maturity of ISO 9000 is usually seen through the S curve. The first year may be said to be embryonic; the second, progressive improvement and maturity come in the third year. If a program is effective or effectively implemented for at least three years, it is called a matured program.
  • Below are the common reasons for the ineffective implementation of ISO 9000.
    1. The main intention of ISO 9000 is marketing and not real quality improvement. Therefore, the top management only looks at the ISO 900 program as a marketing or advertisement tool.
    2. Not focusing on product and service standards and just focusing on the quality management systems.
    3. The overemphasis on Quality Documentation rather than Quality Culture focused.
    4. Emphasis on quality in production and de-emphasis on quality in services.
    5. Not using quality and management tools which are required in the implementation of many requirements (clauses).

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify the new requirements of ISO 9001:2015 and interpret them
    • Discuss the challenges in establishing quality management systems
    • List the main clauses of ISO 9001:2015
    • Summarize the transitional roadmap for effective implementation of ISO 9001:2015
    • Identify the correct management tool to use in the revised ISO standard

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • The introductory clauses of ISO 9001: 2015 are as follows:
    • The Scope: The overall intent and purpose of the standard is not changed from ISO 9001:2008. The requirements of ISO 9001:2015 are intended to be applicable to all organizations and any products and services.
    • Normative References: ISO 9001:2008 cited ISO 9000:2005 QMS fundamentals and vocabulary as a normative reference. They were intended to be used as pairs. ISO 9001:2015 cites ISO 9000:2015 as a normative reference.
    • Terms and Definitions: Some terms are changed or added to the standard and can be interpreted through ISO 9000:2015.
  • SWOT Analysis can be used in identifying the internal and external issues of an organization. There are two broad categories of SWOT Analysis.
    • Internal Factors: This includes strengths and weaknesses of the organization or any specific department of the organization.
    • External Factors: This includes opportunities and threats for the organization as a whole or any department.

    • Terms and Definitions: Some terms are changed or added to the standard and can be interpreted through ISO 9000:2015.

    • Internal Factors: This includes strengths and weaknesses of the organization or any specific department of the organization.
    • External Factors: This includes opportunities and threats for the organization as a whole or any department.
